article.paragraph: Derry(IPAc-enˈdɛrɪcite webhttp://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/derry?showCookiePolicyDerry24 September 2014Collins Dictionaryn.d.), officiallyLondonderry(IPAc-enˈlʌndənˌdɛrɪ), is the second-largestCity status in the United KingdomcityinNorthern Irelandcite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/breathingplaces/cities/lderry/Derry/LondonderryBBC28 August 2008Dead linkSeptember 2010H3llBotcite webhttp://www.ofcom.org.uk/research/cm/cm07/nireland/ni2.pdfThe Communications Market 200714OfcomPDF28 August 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080626114418/http://www.ofcom.org.uk/research/cm/cm07/nireland/ni2.pdf26 June 2008and the fourth-largest city on the island of Ireland.DERRY REGIONAL CITY Business Investment. Retrieved 1 November 2008.waybackhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/economicdevelopment/business.asp20100329101654The name Derry is ananglicisationof the Irish nameDaireorDoiremeaning "oak grove".Library IrelandSketches of Olden Days in Northern Irelandcite bookAnthony David MillsA Dictionary of British Place-Nameshttps://books.google.com/books?id27 June 20126 November 2003Oxford University Press978-0-19-852758-9430–In 1613, the city was granted a Royal Charter byJames I of EnglandKing James Iand gained the "London" prefix to reflect the funding of its construction by the London guilds. While the city is more usually known colloquially as Derry,cite bookRyan Ver BerkmoesOliver BerryGeert ColeDavid ElseWestern Europehttps://books.google.com/books?id30 May 20111 September 2009Lonely Planet978-1-74104-917-6704Londonderry is also commonly used and remains the legal name.

The oldwalled citylies on the west bank of theRiver Foyle, which is spanned by two road bridges and one footbridge. The city now covers both banks (Citysideon the west andWaterside, DerryWatersideon the east). The city district also extends to rural areas to the southeast. The population of the city proper (the area defined by its 17th century charter) was 83,652 in the 2001 Census, while theDerry Urban Areahad a population of 90,736.waybackhttp://www.ninis.nisra.gov.uk/mapxtreme_towns/report.asp?settlementName20140110002557The district is administered by Derry City & Strabane District Council and contains bothLondonderry PortandCity of Derry Airport.

Derry is close to theIrish borderborderwithCounty Donegal, with which it has had a close link for many centuries. The person traditionally seen as the 'founder' of the original Derry is SaintColumbaColmcille, a holy man fromTr Chonaill, the old name for almost all of modern County Donegal (of which the west bank of the Foyle was a part before 1610Brian Lacy (Editor),Archaeological Survey of County Donegal, p. 1.Donegal County Council,Lifford, 1983.).

In 2013, Derry became the inauguralUK City of Culture, having been awarded the title in July 2010.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-10653989Londonderry named the UK City of CultureBBC NewsBBC News15 July 201015 July 2010cite webhttp://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http://www.culture.gov.uk/reference_library/media_releases/6256.aspxThe race is on to find UK's first 'City of Culture' for 2013PalmerRobertThe National Archives15 July 2010
article.heading: Name
article.paragraph: MainDerry/Londonderry name disputeFile:Vandalised road-sign Londonderry P3010060.jpgthumbrightRoad sign in Northern Ireland with the reference to ''London'' obscuredFile:Derry Stranorlar N13 roadsign cropped.JPGthumbrightRoad signs in theRepublic of Ireland(County Donegalshown) use ''Derry'' and the Irish ''Doire''According to the city'sRoyal Charterof 10 April 1662, the official name isLondonderry. This was reaffirmed in a High Court decision in January 2007 when Derry City Council sought guidance on the procedure for effecting a name change.cite webhttp://www.bailii.org/cgi-bin/markup.cgi?docDerry City Council, Re Application for Judicial Review [2007] NIQB 525 January 2007Derry City Council28 August 2008cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6297907.stmStroke City to remain Londonderry25 January 2007BBC28 August 2008The council had changed its name from "Londonderry City Council" to "Derry City Council" in 1984;cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6213890.stmBBC NewsCity name row lands in High Court6 December 20061 May 2010the court case was seeking clarification as to whether this had also changed the name of the city. The decision of the court was that it had not but it was clarified that the correct procedure to do so was via a petition to thePrivy Council.cite webhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/Press%20Releases/250107-name.htmDerry City Council – High Court Provides Clarification on City's NameDerrycity.gov.uk25 January 200720 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20080602043321/http://www.derrycity.gov.uk:80/Press%20Releases/250107-name.htm2 June 2008Derry City Council since started this process and were involved in conducting anDerry-Londonderry name dispute#Equality impact assessmentequality impact assessment report(EQIA).Equality Impact AssessmentsDerry City Council websitewaybackhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/equality-current.htm20081202173814Firstly it held an opinion poll of district residents in 2009, which reported that 75% of Catholics and 77% of Nationalists found the proposed change acceptable, compared to 6% of Protestants and 8% of Unionists.Draft EQIA, Appendix pp.912Then the EQIA held two consultative forums, and solicited comments from the general public on whether or not the city should have its name changed to Derry.A total of 12,136 comments were received, of which 3,108 were broadly in favour of the proposal, and 9,028 opposed to it.cite webhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/Agenda/downloads/special/tcr.docReport of Town Clerk and Chief Executive to Special Council MeetingMcMahonDamien26 February 20101 May 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20070710022228/http://derrycity.gov.uk:80/Agenda/downloads/special/tcr.doc10 July 2007On 23 July 2015, the council voted in favour of a motion to change the official name of the city to Derry and to write toMark H. Durkan, Northern Ireland Minister of the Environment, to ask how the change could be effected.cite newshttp://www.derryjournal.com/news/new-derry-name-bid-disgusting-claim-dup-1-6867330New 'Derry' name bid 'disgusting', claim DUPBrendanMcDaidDerry Journal24 July 201524 July 2014

Despite the official name, the city is more usually known as simplyDerry,cite newshttp://www.derryjournal.com/editorial/What39s-in-a-name-.5699397.jpWhat's in a name?2 October 2009[[Derry Journal]]1 December 2009which is ananglicisationof the IrishDaireorDoire, and translates as "oak-grove/oak-wood". The name derives from the settlement's earliest references,Daire Calgaich("oak-grove of Calgach").cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/irish/blas/education/beginnersblas/3derry.shtmlEducation/OideachasBBC14 July 2007The name was changed from Derry in 1613 during thePlantation of Ulsterto reflect the establishment of the city by the London guilds.cite webhttp://www.collectbritain.co.uk/dlo.cfm/19thphotobooks/006ZZZ001782A19U00012000.htmLondonderryHudsonJohnThe British Library29 September 2007yeshttps://web.archive.org/20071016183941/http://collectbritain.co.uk:80/dlo.cfm/19thphotobooks/006ZZZ001782A19U00012000.htm16 October 2007cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/plantation/companies/londoncompanies_full.rtfThe City of London and the Plantation of UlsterCurlJames Stevens2001BBCi History Online10 August 2008

The name "Derry" is preferred byIrish nationalismnationalistsand it is broadly used throughout Northern Ireland's Catholic community,cite webhttp://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/segregat/temple/discus1.htmAspects of Sectarian Division in Derry Londonderry – First public discussion: The Name Of this City?15 June 2008as well as that of the Republic of Ireland, whereas manyUnionists (Ireland)unionistsprefer "Londonderry";cite journal10.1111/j.0435-3684.2001.00100.xKuusisto-ArponenAnna-Kaisa2001The end of violence and introduction of 'real' politics: Tensions in peaceful Northern IrelandGeografiska Annaler: Series B, Human Geography833121–130491073Blackwell Publishinghowever in everyday conversation Derry is used by most Protestant residents of the city.War zone language: linguistic aspects of the conflict in Northern Irelandby Cordula Hawes-Bilger (ISBN 978-3-7720-8200-9), page 100Linguist Kevin McCafferty argues that "It is not, strictly speaking, correct that Northern Ireland Catholics call it Derry, while Protestants use the Londonderry form, although this pattern has become more common locally since the mid-1980s, when the city council changed its name by dropping the prefix". In McCafferty's survey of language use in the city, "only very few intervieweesall Protestantsuse the official form".cite bookEthnicity and Language Change: English in (London)Derry, Northern IrelandKevinMcCaffertyAmsterdamJohn Benjamins Publishing20016978-1588110022

Apart from the name of Derry City Council, the city is usuallyknown as Londonderry in official use within the UK. In the Republic of Ireland, the city and county are almost always referred to as Derry, on maps, in the media and in conversation.cite webhttp://www.irishrail.ie/images/maps/intercity_map.gifIrish Rail network showing 'Derry'29 July 2009[[Iarnród Éireann]]yeshttps://web.archive.org/20081118043852/http://www.irishrail.ie//images/maps/intercity_map.gif18 November 2008In April 2009, however, the Republic of Ireland's Minister for Foreign Affairs,Michel Martin, announced that Irish passport holders who were born there could record either Derry or Londonderry as their place of birth.cite newsCarrollStephenDerry-born can choose city's name on passporthttp://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0409/1224244287427.html23 July 2015Irish Times9 April 2009Whereas official road signs in the Republic use the nameDerry, those in Northern Ireland bearLondonderry(sometimes abbreviated toL'Derry), although some of these have been defaced with the reference toLondonobscured.cite bookDavenportFionnBeech, CharlotteDowns, TomHannigan, DesParnell, FranWilson, NeilIrelandLonely PlanetLondon20067th625https://books.google.com/?id978-1-74059-968-9Usage varies among local organisations, with both names being used. Examples areCity of Derry Airport,City of Derry Rugby Club,Derry City FCand the ProtestantApprentice Boys of Derry, as opposed toLondonderry Port, Londonderry YMCA Rugby Club and Londonderry Chamber of Commerce.cite webhttp://www.londonderrychamber.co.uk/Londonderry Chamber of CommerceLondonderrychamber.co.uk20 June 2010Most companies within the city choose local area names such as Pennyburn, Rosemount or "Foyle" from theRiver Foyleto avoid alienating the other community.Londonderry railway stationis often referred to as Waterside railway station within the city but is called Derry/Londonderry at other stations. The council changed the name of the local government district covering the city to Derry on 7 May 1984, consequently renaming itself Derry City Council.Change of District Name (Derry) Order 1984This did not change the name of the city, although the city is coterminous with the district, and in law the city council is also the "Corporation of Londonderry" or, more formally, the "Mayor, Aldermen and Citizens of the City of Londonderry".Sections 7, 8 and 132 of the Local Government Act (Northern Ireland) 1972 (Eliz II 20 & 21 c.9)The form "Londonderry" is used for thepost townby theRoyal Mail,however use of Derry will still ensure delivery.

The city is also nicknamedthe Maiden Cityby virtue of the fact that its walls were never breached despite being besieged on three separate occasions in the 17th century, the most notable being theSiege of Derryof 1688/89.cite webhttp://www.discovernorthernireland.com/article.aspx?ArticleIDThe Walled City ExperienceNorthern Ireland Tourist Board4 September 2008It is also nicknamedSlash (punctuation)StrokeCityby local broadcaster,Gerry Anderson (broadcaster)Gerry Anderson, due to the 'politically correct' use of the oblique notation Derry/Londonderry(which appellation has itself been used byBBC TelevisionThe One Show, BBC1, 15 July2010). A recent addition to the landscape has been the erection of several large stone columns on main roads into the city welcoming drivers, euphemistically, to "the walled city".

The name Derry is very much in popular use throughout Ireland for the naming of places, and there are at least six towns bearing that name and at least a further 79 places. The word Derry often forms part of the place name, for example Derrybeg, Derryboy, Derrylea and Derrymore.

The names Derry and Londonderry are not limited to Ireland. There is a town calledDerry, New HampshireDerrysituated right beside another town calledLondonderry, New HampshireLondonderryinNew Hampshirein the US. There are also Londonderrys inYorkshire, England, inVermont, USA, inNova Scotia, Canada, and in northern and eastern Australia.Londonderry Islandis situated offTierra del Fuegoin Chile.
Derry (Stephen King)Derryis also a fictional town in Maine, USA, used in some Stephen King novels.cite webhttp://www.stephenking.com/images/map_of_maine.jpgStephen King's Map of Maine13 May 2012
article.heading: City walls
article.paragraph: anchorWallsFile:Cannon on Derry City Walls SMC 2007.jpgthumbrightA portion of the city walls of Derry.File:Bishops Street Gate Derry SMC 2007.jpgthumbrightBishops Street GateDerry is the only remaining completely intact walled city in Ireland and one of the finest examples of a walled city in Europe.cite webhttp://www.brilliantireland.com/products/inc_productdetails.cfm/product_key/46Web Development Belfast | Web solutions Ireland | Biznet IIS Northern IrelandBrilliantireland.com20 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20080821103657/http://www.brilliantireland.com//products/inc_productdetails.cfm/product_key/4621 August 2008cite webhttp://www.roughguides.com/website/Travel/Destination/content/default.aspx?titleidAntrim and DerryRoughguides.com20 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20100722050711/http://www.roughguides.com:80/website/Travel/Destination/content/default.aspx?titleid22 July 2010cite webhttp://www.irelandwide.com/regional/ulster/county_derry/index.htmCounty Derry, Northern Ireland – LondonderryIrelandwide.com20 June 2010The walls constitute the largest monument in State care in Northern Ireland and, as the last walled city to be built in Europe, stands as the most complete and spectacular.cite webhttp://www.ni-environment.gov.uk/derry-lowres.pdfDerry City Walls Conservation Plan. pdf doc. p19

The Walls were built during the period 16131619 byThe Honourable The Irish Societyas defences for early 17th century settlers from England and Scotland. The Walls, which are approximatelyconvert1mikmin circumference and which vary in height and width betweenconvert12and35ftmoffflip, are completely intact and form a walkway around the inner city. They provide a unique promenade to view the layout of the original town which still preserves its Renaissance style street plan. The four original gates to the Walled City are Bishop's Gate, Ferryquay Gate, Butcher Gate and Shipquay Gate. Three further gates were added later, Magazine Gate, Castle Gate and New Gate, making seven gates in total. Historic buildings within the walls include the 1633 GothicSt Columb's Cathedralcathedral of St Columb, the Apprentice Boys Memorial Hall and the courthouse.

It is one of the few cities in Europe that never saw its fortifications breached, withstanding several sieges including one in 1689 which lasted 105 days, hence the city's nickname, The Maiden City.Historic Walls of DerryDiscover Northern Ireland website
article.heading: History
Early history
article.paragraph:
Derry is one of the oldest continuously inhabited places in Ireland.cite bookLacey Brian Discover Derry The O'Brien Press Ltd Dublin City Guides 1999
0-86278-596-0The earliest historical references date to the 6th century when amonasterywas founded there by StColumbaor Colmcille, a famous saint from what is nowCounty Donegal, but for thousands of years before that people had been living in the vicinity.

Before leaving Ireland to spread Christianity elsewhere, Colmcille founded a monastery at Derry (which was then calledDoire Calgach), on the west bank of the Foyle. According to oral and documented history, the site was granted to Colmcille by a local king.cite webhttp://www.geographia.com/norThern-ireland/ukider01.htm History of Derry 13 February 2010 www.geographia.comThe monastery then remained in the hands of the federation of Columban churches who regarded Colmcille as their spiritual mentor. The year 546 is often referred to as the date that the original settlement was founded. However, it is now accepted by historians that this was an erroneous date assigned by medieval chroniclers.It is accepted that between the 6th century and the 11th century, Derry was known primarily as a monastic settlement.

The town became strategically more significant during theTudor conquest of Irelandand came under frequent attack. DuringO'Doherty's Rebellionin 1608 it was attacked byCahir O'DohertySir Cahir O'Doherty, Irish chieftain ofInishowen, whoBurning of Derryburnt much of the townand killed the governorGeorge Paulet.cite webhttp://www.irishtimes.com/focus/earls/theflight/flight3.html King ponders plantation 13 February 2010 www.irishtimes.com/Dead linkJanuary 2014The soldier and statesmanHenry Docwra, 1st Baron Docwra of CulmoreSir Henry Docwramade vigorous efforts to develop the town, earning the reputation of being " the founder of Derry"; but he was accused of failing to prevent the O'Doherty attack, and returned to England.
article.heading: Plantation
article.paragraph: What became the City of Derry was part of the relatively newCounty Donegalup until 1610.Brian Lacy,Archaeological Survey of County Donegal, p. 1.Donegal County Council,Lifford, 1983.In that year, the west bank of the future city was transferred by theEnglish CrowntoThe Honourable The Irish Societyand was combined withCounty Coleraine, part ofCounty Antrimand a large portion ofCounty Tyroneto formCounty Londonderry. Planters organised by Londonlivery companiesthroughThe Honourable The Irish Societyarrived in the 17th century as part of thePlantation of Ulster, and rebuilt the town with high walls to defend it from Irish insurgents who opposed the plantation. The aim was to settle Ulster with a population supportive of the Crown.It was then renamed "Londonderry".

This city was the firstplanned cityin Ireland: it was begun in 1613, with the walls being completed in 1619, at a cost of 10,757.cite webhttp://www.derryswalls.com/hist-walls-constructed.htmlWalls Constructed23 July 2012Guildhall Press2005–2008Derry's WallsThe central diamond within a walled city with four gates was thought to be a good design for defence. The grid pattern chosen was subsequently much copied in the colonies of British North America.cite webhttp://worldfacts.us/UK-Londonderry.htmWorld Facts Index >United Kingdom >Londonderry2005worldfacts.us5 September 2006The charter initially defined the city as extending threeIrish miles(about 6.1 km) from the centre.

The modern city preserves the 17th century layout of four main streets radiating from a central Diamond to four gateways   Bishop's Gate, Ferryquay Gate, Shipquay Gate and Butcher's Gate. The city's oldest surviving building was also constructed at this time: the 1633 Plantation GothicSt Columb's Cathedralcathedral of St Columb. In the porch of the cathedral is a stone that records completion with the inscription: "If stones could speake, then London's prayse should sound, Who built this church and cittie from the grounde."cite webhttp://www.stcolumbscathedral.org/History.htmBRIEF HISTORY OF ST COLUMB'S CATHEDRAL LONDONDERRY13 February 2010www.stcolumbscathedral.orgyeshttps://web.archive.org/20090104025334/http://www.stcolumbscathedral.org:80/history.htm4 January 2009
article.heading: 17th-century upheavals
article.paragraph: During the 1640s, the city suffered in theWars of the Three Kingdoms, which began with theIrish Rebellion of 1641, when the Gaelic Irish insurgents made a failed attack on the city. In 1649 the city and its garrison, which supported the republicanParliament of EnglandParliamentin London, were besieged by ScottishPresbyterianforces loyal to KingCharles I of EnglandCharles I. The Parliamentarians besieged in Derry were relieved by a strange alliance ofRoundheadtroops underGeorge Monckand the Irish Catholic generalOwen Roe O'Neill. These temporary allies were soon fighting each other again however, after the landing in Ireland of theNew Model Armyin 1649. The war in Ulster was finally brought to an end when the Parliamentarians crushed the Irish Catholic Ulster army at theBattle of Scarrifholis, nearLetterkennyin nearbyCounty Donegal, in 1650.

During theGlorious Revolution, only Derry and nearbyEnniskillenhad a Protestant garrison by November 1688. An army of around 1,200 men, mostly "Redshanks" (Scottish HighlandsHighlanders), under Alexander Macdonnell, 3rd Earl of Antrim, was slowly organised (they set out on the week William of Orange landed in England). When they arrived on 7 December 1688 the gates were closed against them and theSiege of Derrybegan. In April 1689, King James came to the city and summoned it to surrender. The King was rebuffed and the siege lasted until the end of July with the arrival of a relief ship.
article.heading: 18th and 19th centuries
article.paragraph: File:1837Londonderry.jpgthumbuprightMap of County Londonderry 1837The city was rebuilt in the 18th century with many of its fineGeorgian architectureGeorgianstyle houses still surviving. The city's first bridge across the River Foyle was built in 1790. During the 18th and 19th centuries the port became an important embarkation point for Irish emigrants setting out for North America. Some of these founded the colonies ofDerry (disambiguation)DerryandLondonderry, New HampshireLondonderryin the state ofNew Hampshire.

Also during the 19th century, it became a destination for migrants fleeing areas more severely affected by theThe Great HungerIrish Potato Famine.cite journalThe population of Londonderry during the Great Irish FamineThe Economic History ReviewJohnsonJames H.1957102273–28510.2307/25908632590863Blackwell PublishingPage 67 "Derry beyond the walls" by SDLP politician John HumeOne of the most notable shipping lines was theMcCorkell Lineoperated by Wm. McCorkell & Co. Ltd. from 1778.http://www.mccorkellline.com/ McCorkell LineThe McCorkell's most famous ship was the Minnehaha, which was known as the "Green Yacht from Derry".
article.heading: Early 20th century
World War I
article.paragraph: The city contributed over 5,000 men to the British Army from Catholic and Protestant families.
article.heading: Partition
article.paragraph: File:War memorial Derry 2007 SMC.jpgthumbuprightThe war memorial in The Diamond, erected 1927cite webhttp://www.localhistories.org/derry.htmlA Brief History of DerryLambertTimLocal Histories.org28 March 2008During theIrish War of Independence, the area was rocked by sectarian violence, partly prompted by the guerilla war raging between theIrish Republican Army (191722)Irish Republican Armyand British forces, but also influenced by economic and social pressures. By mid-1920 there was severe sectarian rioting in the city.cite webhttp://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2009/0624/1224249415663.html June 24th, 1920: Pitched battles on the streets of Derry 13 February 2010 JOYCE JOE 24 June 2009 www.irishtimes.comcite webhttp://saoirse.21.forumer.com/viewtopic.php?tThis is a chronology of Irish War of Independence 13 February 2010 saoirse.21.forumer.comMany lives were lost and in addition many Catholics and Protestants were expelled from their homes during this communal unrest. After a week's violence, a truce was negotiated by local politicians on both unionist and republican sides.
In 1921, following theAnglo-Irish Treatyand thePartition of Ireland, it unexpectedly became a 'border city', separated from much of its traditional economic hinterland inCounty Donegal.
article.heading: World War II
article.paragraph: DuringWorld War II, the city played an important part in theBattle of the Atlantic (19391945)Battle of the Atlantic.cite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/features/Derry-was-39best-kept-secret39.4586787.jp Derry was 'best kept secret' in Battle of the Atlantic 13 February 2010 Cullen Ian 13 October 2008 Derry JournalShips from theRoyal Navy, theRoyal Canadian Navy, and other Allied navies were stationed in the city and the United States military established a base. Over 20,000Royal Navy, 10,000Royal Canadian Navy, and 6,000American Navypersonnel were stationed in the city during the war.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/radiofoyle/peoples_war/context.shtmlBBC Online – Northern Ireland – Radio FoyleBbc.co.uk13 May 2012The establishment of the American presence in the city was the result of a secret agreement between the Americans and the British before the Americans entered the war.cite webhttp://www.culturenorthernireland.org/article/447/world-war-two-in-derryWorld War Two in DerryCulturenorthernireland.org13 May 2012It was the first American naval base in Europe and the terminal for American convoys en route to Europe.

The reason for such a high degree of military and naval activity was self-evident: Derry was the United Kingdom's westernmost port; indeed, the city was the westernmost Allied port in Europe: thus, Derry was a crucial jumping-off point, together with Glasgow and Liverpool, for the shipping convoys that ran between Europe and North America. The large numbers of military personnel in Derry substantially altered the character of the city, bringing in some outside colour to the local area, as well as some cosmopolitan and economic buoyancy during these years. Several airfields were built in the outlying regions of the city at this time, Maydown, Eglinton and Ballykelly. RAF Eglinton went on to becomeCity of Derry Airport.

The city contributed significant number of men to the war effort throughout the services, most notably the 500 men in the 9th (Londonderry) Heavy Anti-Aircraft Regiment, known as the 'Derry Boys'. This regiment served in North Africa, the Sudan, Italy and mainland UK. Many others served in the Merchant Navy taking part in the convoys that supplied the UK and Russia during the war.
The border location of the city, and influx of trade from the military convoys allowed for significant smuggling operations to develop in the city.

At the conclusion of the Second World War, eventually some 60 U-boats of the GermanKriegsmarineended in the city's harbour atLisahallyafter their surrender.cite webhttp://www.secondworldwarni.org/print.aspx?pagerecordidThe U-boat surrender 13 February 2010 www.secondworldwarni.orgThe initial surrender was attended by Admiral SirMax Kennedy HortonMax Horton, Commander-in-Chief of theWestern Approaches, and SirBasil Brooke, 1st Viscount BrookeboroughBasil Brooke, thirdPrime Minister of Northern Ireland.
article.heading: Late 20th century
1950s and 1960s
article.paragraph: The city languished after the second world war, with unemployment and development stagnating. A large campaign, led by theUniversity for Derry Committee, to have Northern Ireland's second university located in the city, ended in failure.
article.heading: The Civil Rights Movement
article.paragraph: Derry was a focal point for the nascent civil rights movement in Northern Ireland.

File:Bogside Derry SMC 2005.jpgthumbrightBogside area viewed from the wallsCatholics were discriminated against under Unionist government inNorthern Ireland, both politically and economically.Explaining Northern Ireland: broken imagesby John McGarry, Brendan O'Leary (ISBN 978-0631183495), pages 205206Race and inequality: world perspectives on affirmative actionby Elaine Kennedy-Dubourdieu (ISBN 978-0754648390), page 108The Irish Catholic diaspora in Americaby Lawrence John McCaffrey (ISBN 978-0813208961), page 168cite webhttp://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/discrimination/chron.htm Discrimination – Chronology of Important Events 13 February 2010 6 January 2009 cain.ulst.ac.ukIn the late 1960s the city became the flashpoint of disputes about institutionalgerrymandering.Political sciencePolitical scientistJohn Henry WhyteJohn Whyteexplains that:

paragraph.extension: All the accusations of gerrymandering, practically all the complaints about housing and regional policy, and a disproportionate amount of the charges about public and private employment come from this area. The area which consisted of Counties Tyrone and Fermanagh, Londonderry County Borough, and portions of Counties Londonderry and Armagh had less than a quarter of the total population of Northern Ireland yet generated not far short of three-quarters of the complaints of discrimination...The unionist government must bear its share of responsibility. It put through the original gerrymander which underpinned so many of the subsequent malpractices, and then, despite repeated protests, did nothing to stop those malpractices continuing. The most serious charge against the Northern Ireland government is not that it was directly responsible for widespread discrimination, but that it allowed discrimination on such a scale over a substantial segment of Northern Ireland.cite bookWhyteJohnContemporary Irish StudiesGallagher, Tom; O'Connell, JamesManchester University PressManchester1983How much discrimination was there under the unionist regime, 1921–68?0-7190-0919-7http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/discrimination/whyte.htm#chap1

article.paragraph: Acivil rightsdemonstration in 1968 led by theNorthern Ireland Civil Rights Associationwas banned by the Government and blocked using force by theRoyal Ulster Constabulary.The events that followed the August 1969Apprentice Boysparade resulted in theBattle of the Bogside, when Catholic rioters fought the police, leading to widespread civil disorder in Northern Ireland and is often dated as the starting point ofthe Troubles.

On Sunday 30 January 1972, 13 unarmed civilians were shot dead by British paratroopers during a civil rights march in theBogsidearea. Another 13 were wounded and one further man later died of his wounds. This event came to be known asBloody Sunday (Northern Ireland 1972)Bloody Sunday.
article.heading: The Troubles
article.paragraph: MainThe Troubles in DerryFile:Free Derry Corner in 1969.jpgthumb300pxright"Free Derry Corner" at the corner of Lecky Road and Fahan Street in the Bogside. The slogan was first painted in January 1969 by John Casey.The conflict which became known as the Troubles is widely regarded as having started in Derry with the Battle of the Bogside. The Civil Rights movement had also been very active in the city. In the early 1970s the city was heavily militarised and there was widespread civil unrest. Several districts in the city constructed barricades to control access and prevent the forces of the state from entering.

Violence eased towards the end of the Troubles in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Irish journalist Ed Maloney claims in "The Secret History of the IRA" that republican leaders there negotiated ade factoceasefire in the city as early as 1991. Whether this is true or not, the city did see less bloodshed by this time than Belfast or other localities.

The city was visited by akiller whalein November 1977 at the height of the Troubles; it was dubbed Dopey Dick by the thousands who came from miles around to see him.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/radiofoyle/dopeydick/A whale of a timeBBC Radio Foyle12 October 2008
article.heading: Governance
article.paragraph: The local district council isDerry City Council, which consists of five electoral areas: Cityside, Northland, Rural,ShantallowandWaterside, DerryWaterside. The council of 30 members is re-elected every four years. As of the 2011 election, 14Social Democratic and Labour Party(SDLP) members, tenSinn Fin, fiveDemocratic Unionist Party(DUP), and oneUlster Unionist Party(UUP) make up the council.Update after2010115The mayor and deputy mayor are elected annually by councillors.

The local authority boundaries correspond to theFoyle (UK Parliament constituency)Foyle constituencyof theParliament of the United Kingdomand theFoyle (Assembly constituency)Foyle constituencyof theNorthern Ireland Assembly. InEuropean Parliamentelections, it is part of theNorthern Ireland (European Parliament constituency)Northern Ireland constituency.
article.heading: Coat of arms and motto
article.paragraph: File:Coat of arms of Derry.pngthumbuprightDerry's coat of armsThe devices on the city's arms are a skeleton and a three-towered castle on a black field, with thechiefor top third of the shield depicting the arms of theCity of London: a red cross and sword on white. In the centre of the cross is a gold harp.Theblazonof the arms is as follows:

paragraph.italics: Sable, a human skeleton Or seated upon a mossy stone proper and in dexter chief a castle triple towered argent on a chief also argent a cross gules thereon a harp or and in the first quarter a sword erect gules
paragraph.extension: Letters Patent certifying the arms of the City of Londonderry issued to Derry City Council, sealed by Garter and Norroy and Ulster Kings of Arms dated 30 April 2003

article.paragraph: According to documents in theCollege of Armsin London and theOffice of the Chief Herald of Irelandin Dublin, the arms of the city were confirmed in 1613 by Daniel Molyneux,Ulster King of Arms.The College of Arms document states that the original arms of the City of Derry wereye picture of death (or a skeleton) on a moissy stone & in ye dexter point a castleand that upon grant of a charter of incorporation and the renaming of the city as Londonderry in that year the first mayor had requested the addition of a "chief of London".Genealogical Office, Dublin: GO Ms 60,Sketches of arms by Richard Carney, fol. 47College of Arms, London:The Arms of Peers of Ireland and some Commoners, fol. 133d (c.1652)
Theories have been advanced as to the meaning of the "old" arms of Derry, before the addition of the chief bearing the arms of the City of London:

list.listitem: A suggestion has been made that the castle is related to an early 14th-century castle in nearbyGreencastle, County DonegalGreencastlebelonging to the Anglo-NormanEarl of UlsterRichard g de Burgh, 2nd Earl of UlsterRichard de Burgh.

The most popular theory about the skeleton is that it is that of aNormansNormanDe Burgh knight who was starved to death in the castle dungeons in 1332 on the orders of his cousin the above-mentionedEarl of Ulster.Another explanation put forward was that it depictedCahir O'Doherty(Sir Charles O'Dogherty), who was put to death after Derry was invested by the English army in 1608. During the days ofGerrymanderingand discrimination against the Catholic population of Derry, Derry's Roman Catholics often used to claim in dark wit that the skeleton was a local waiting for help from the council bureaucracy.

article.paragraph: In 1979, Londonderry City Council, as it was then known, commissioned a report into the city's arms and insignia, as part of the design process for anheraldic badge. The published report found that there was no basis for any of the popular explanations for the skeleton and that it was "purely symbolic and does not refer to any identifiable person".L E Rothwell,An inquiry initiated by Derry City Council into the ensigns armourial and related matters of the City of Londonderry

The 1613 records of the arms depicted a harp in the centre of the cross, but this was omitted from later depictions of the city arms, and in theLetters Patentconfirming the arms to Londonderry Corporation in 1952.Letters Patent ratifying and confirming the arms of the City of Londonderry sealed by Garter and Norroy & Ulster Kings of Arms dated 28 April 1952In 2002 Derry City Council applied to the College of Arms to have the harp restored to the city arms, andGarter Principal King of ArmsGarterandNorroy and Ulster King of ArmsNorroy & UlsterKings of Arms accepted the 17th century evidence, issuing letters patent to that effect in 2003.
The motto attached to the coat of arms reads in Latin, "Vita, Veritas, Victoria". This translates into English as, "Life, Truth, Victory".

article.heading: Geography
article.paragraph: File:OpenStreetMap of DerryLondonderry UK Apr2012.pngthumbOpenstreetMap mappingFile:Craigavon bridge.jpgthumbrightTheCraigavon Bridge.Derry is characterised by its distinctively hilly topography.cite webhttp://www.ni-environment.gov.uk/landscape/country_landscape/32/32-land.htm Derry Slopes Landscape 13 February 2010 DOENITheRiver Foyleforms a deep valley as it flows through the city, making Derry a place of very steep streets and sudden, startling views. The originalwalled cityof Londonderry lies on a hill on the west bank of the River Foyle. In the past, the river branched and enclosed this wooded hill as an island; over the centuries, however, the western branch of the river dried up and became a low-lying and boggy district that is now called the Bogside.cite webhttp://www.museumoffreederry.org/history-bogside01.html History–The Bogside 13 February 2010 Museum of Free Derry

Today, modern Derry extends considerably north and west of the city walls and east of the river. The half of the city the west of the Foyle is known as the Cityside and the area east is called theWaterside, DerryWaterside. The Cityside and Waterside are connected by theCraigavon BridgeandFoyle Bridge, and by a foot bridge in the centre of the city calledPeace Bridge (Foyle)Peace Bridge. The district also extends into rural areas to the southeast of the city.

This much larger city, however, remains characterised by the often extremely steep hills that form much of its terrain on both sides of the river. A notable exception to this lies on the north-eastern edge of the city, on the shores of Lough Foyle, where large expanses of sea and mudflats were reclaimed in the middle of the 19th century. Today, these slob lands are protected from the sea by miles of sea walls and dikes. The area is an internationally important bird sanctuary, ranked among the top 30 wetland sites in the UK.cite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/journal/Concerns-over-Lough-Foyle-bird.6066202.jp Concerns over Lough Foyle bird numbers 13 February 2010 Wilson David 12 February 2010 Derry Journal

Other important nature reserves lie at Ness Country Park,cite webhttp://www.ni-environment.gov.uk/places_to_visit_home/parks/ness.htm Ness Country Park 13 February 2010 DOENIDead linkJanuary 2014convert10mikmeast of Derry; and at Prehen Wood,cite webhttp://www.discovernorthernireland.com/Prehen-Wood-Londonderry-Derry-P11676 Prehen Wood 13 February 2010 Northern Ireland Tourist Boarddead linkApril 2015within the city's south-eastern suburbs.

article.heading: Demography
article.paragraph: File:Ebrington Square, Derry,.jpgthumbrightEbrington SquareDerry Urban Area (DUA), including the city and the neighbouring settlements ofCulmore,NewbuildingsandStrathfoyle, is classified as a city by the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA) since its population exceeds 75,000. On census day (27 March 2011) there were 105,066 people living inDerry Urban Area. Of these, 27% were aged under 16 years and 14% were aged 60 and over; 49% of the population were male and 51% were female; 75% were from aRoman Catholicbackground and 23% (up three percent from 2001) were from aProtestantbackground.cite webhttp://www.nisra.gov.uk/Census/2011_results_population.htmlCensus 2011 – Population and Household Estimates for Northern IrelandNorthern Ireland Statistics & Research Agency24 September 2012

The mid-2006 population estimate for the widerDerry City Councilarea was 107,300.cite webhttp://www.nisra.gov.uk/archive/demography/publications/pr_mye_2006.pdfStatistics press notice: Mid-year population estimates Northern Ireland (2006)Northern Ireland Statistics & Research Agency31 July 200728 August 2008PDFhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080626114426/http://www.nisra.gov.uk/archive/demography/publications/pr_mye_2006.pdf26 June 2008Population growth in 2005/06 was driven by natural change, with net out-migration of approximately 100 people.
The city was one of the few in Ireland to experience an increase in population during theThe Great HungerIrish Potato Famineas migrants came to it from other, more heavily affected areas.
article.heading: Protestant minority
article.paragraph: File:Nosurrender mural derry.jpgthumbright"No Surrender"muraloutside city wallConcerns have been raised by both communities over the increasingly divided nature of the city. There were about 17,000 Protestants on the west bank of the River Foyle in 1971.cite webhttp://cain.ulst.ac.uk/proni/1979/proni_CENT-1-8-11A_1979-01-11.pdfLondonderry population movement from West bank to East bank11 January 1979The proportion then rapidly declined;cite webhttp://cain.ulst.ac.uk/proni/1978/proni_CENT-1-8-11A_1978-11-06.pdfNote of a meeting between Secretary of State and William Ross Unionist MP6 November 1978Public Records Office of Northern Irelandthere are now only about 2,000 on the west bank,cite newshttp://www.londonderrysentinel.co.uk/news/catholics-outnumber-protestants-on-both-banks-of-the-foyle-1-4737478Catholics outnumber Protestants on both banks of the FoyleLondonderry Sentinel31 January 2013KevinMullenaccessdateand it is feared that the city could become permanently divided.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6060810.stmCatholics urged to support neighboursBBC News18 October 200628 August 2008cite webhttp://www.ofmdfmni.gov.uk/derryreport.pdfPopulation Change and Social Inclusion Study: Derry/LondonderryPeter Shirlow, Brian Graham, Amanda McMullan, Brendan Murtagh, Gillian Robinson and Neil SouthernOffice of the First Minister and Deputy First Minister200527 March 2008PDF

However, concerted efforts have been made by local community, church and political leaders from both traditions to redress the problem. A conference to bring together key actors and promote tolerance was held in October 2006.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6060810.stmCatholics urged to support neighbours18 October 2006BBC News28 August 2008The Rt Rev. Dr Ken Good, theChurch of IrelandBishop ofDiocese of Derry and RaphoeDerry and Raphoe, said he was happy living on the cityside. "I feel part of it. It is my city and I want to encourage other Protestants to feel exactly the same", he said.

Support for Protestants in the district has been strong from the former SDLP city MayorHelen Quigley. Cllr Quigley has made inclusion and tolerance key themes of her mayoralty. The Mayor Helen Quigley said it is time for "everyone to take a stand to stop the scourge of sectarian and other assaults in the city."cite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/editorial/Taking-a-stand.1620934.jpTaking a Stand Derry Journal Editorial11 July 2006Derry Journal28 August 2008Dead linkJanuary 2014
article.heading: Economy
History
article.paragraph: The economy of the district was based significantly on the textile industry until relatively recently. For many years women were often the sole wage earners working in the shirt factories while the men predominantly in comparison had high levels of unemployment.cite webhttp://www.recirca.com/backissues/c95/dwc.shtmlWomen, art and architecture appear to have achieved a rare symbiosis in a new project in Derry2001Declan Sheehan CIRCA 955 September 2006yeshttps://web.archive.org/20060528155727/http://www.recirca.com/backissues/c95/dwc.shtml28 May 2006This led to significant male emigration.cite webhttp://www.bloodysundaytrust.org/eduhistory.htmHistory of the BogsideBloody Sunday Trust5 September 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060823085030/http://www.bloodysundaytrust.org/eduhistory.htm23 August 2006The history of shirt making in the city dates back as far as 1831 and is said to have been started by William Scott and his family who first exported shirts toGlasgow.cite webhttp://www.geocities.com/historyofshirtmakinginderry/shirtmakinginderry.htmDerrys association with shirt makingGeoCities.com5 September 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20071225221059/http://www.geocities.com/historyofshirtmakinginderry/shirtmakinginderry.htm25 December 2007Within 50 years, shirt making in the city was the most prolific in the UK with garments being exported all over the world. It was known so well that the industry received a mention inDas KapitalbyKarl Marx, when discussing the factory system:Blockquote<arg name="The shirt factory of Messrs. Tille at Londonderry, which employs 1,000 operatives in the factory itself, and 9,000 people spread up and down the country and working in their own houses.{{cite web|url">http://www.econlib.org/library/YPDBooks/Marx/mrxCpAtoc.html|titleThe industry reached its peak in the 1920s employing around 18,000 people.In modern times however the textile industry declined due to in most part cheaper Asian wages.cite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/features/Thriving-industry-is-no-more.4184442.jpThriving industry is no more: Glory days of shirt factories recalled13 June 2008Derry Journal Online15 June 2008

A long-term foreign employer in the area isDu Pont, which has been based at Maydown since 1958, its first European production facility.cite webhttp://heritage.dupont.com/touchpoints/tp_1958/depth.shtmlFirst European Plant –1958heritage.dupont.com.5 September 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060317060124/http://heritage.dupont.com/touchpoints/tp_1958/depth.shtml17 March 2006OriginallyNeoprenewas manufactured at Maydown and subsequently followed byHypalon. More recentlyLycraandKevlarproduction units were active.cite webhttp://www.northernireland.gov.uk/Du Pont (UK) LtdNorthern Ireland Executive5 September 2006Thanks to a healthy worldwide demand for Kevlar which is made at the plant, the facility recently undertook a 40 million upgrade to expand its global Kevlar production. Du Pont has stated that contributing factors to its continued commitment to Maydown are "low labor costs, excellent communications, and tariff-free, easy access to the Britain and European continent."
article.heading: Inward investment
article.paragraph: File:Seagate building Derry 2005.jpgrightthumbnailSeagate production facilityIn the last 15 years there has been a drive to increase inward investment in the city, more recently concentrating on digital industries. Currently the three largest private-sector employers are American firms.cite webhttp://www.state.gov/s/p/rem/13319.htmU.S.-Irish Business SummitN. HaassRichard6 September 2002Richard N. Haass, director, Policy Planning Staff, Remarks to the US – Irish Business Summit, Washington, D.C.5 September 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060901165901/http://www.state.gov/s/p/rem/13319.htm1 September 2006Economic successes have included call centres and a large investment bySeagate TechnologySeagate, which has operated a factory in the Springtown Industrial Estate since 1993. Seagate currently employs over 1,000 people, producing more than half of the company's total requirement forhard driveread-write heads.

A controversial new employer in the area wasRaytheonRaytheon Systems Limited, a software division of the American defence contractor, which was set up in Derry in 1999.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/428973.stmUK: Northern Ireland Software centre plans under fire25 June 1999BBC15 December 2009Although some of the local people welcomed the jobs boost, others in the area objected to the jobs being provided by a firm involved heavily in thearms industryarms trade.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/2886611.stmProtest over NI missile firm25 March 2003BBC27 August 2006Following four years of protest by the Foyle Ethical Investment Campaign, in 2004 Derry City Council passed a motion declaring the district a "A 'No  Go' Area for the Arms Trade",cite webhttp://www.indymedia.ie/article/62917Derry City Now A 'No – Go' Area for the Arms Trade8 January 2004www.indymedia.ie19 July 2006and in 2006 its offices were briefly occupied by anti-war protestors who became known as theRaytheon 9.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/4776051.stmDefence firm protesters arrestedBBC News20 September 20159 August 2006In 2009, the company announced that it was not renewing its lease when it expired in 2010 and was looking for a new location for its operations.cite webhttp://www.londonderrysentinel.co.uk/news/Raytheon-looks-for-new-home.5381105.jpRaytheon looks for new home19 June 2009[[Londonderry Sentinel]]15 December 2009

Significant multinational employers in the region include Firstsource of India,DuPont,INVISTA, Stream International,Seagate Technology, Perfecseal,ArqivaNTL,RaytheonandNorthbrook Technologyof the United States, Arntz Belting and Invision Software of Germany, and Homeloan Management of the UK. Major local business employers include Desmonds, Northern Ireland's largest privately owned company, manufacturing and sourcing garments, E&I Engineering,Saint Brendan'sSt. Brendan's Irish Cream Liqueurand McCambridge Duffy, one of the largest insolvency practices in the UK.cite webhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/economicdevelopment/downloads/1709M%20DERRY%20BOOK.pdfhttp://www.webcitation.org/5QP38yOrY2007-07-17Derry – Regional CityDerry City Council8 April 2008PDF

Even though the city provides cheap labour by standards in Western Europe, critics have noted that the grants offered by the Northern Ireland Industrial Development Board have helped land jobs for the area that only last as long as the funding lasts.cite webhttp://www.marxist.net/ireland/beyondframe.htm?ch8.htmBeyond the Troubles? – Chapter 8, Will there be peace?HaddenPeter1994Marxist5 September 2006This was reflected in questions to theParliamentary Under-Secretary of Statefor Northern Ireland,Richard Needham, in 1990.cite webhttp://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/cm198990/cmhansrd/1990-03-01/Orals-1.htmlHouse of Commons – Column 372 & 3731 March 1990House of Commons5 September 2006It was noted that it cost 30,000 to create one job in an American firm in Northern Ireland.

Critics of investment decisions affecting the district often point to the decision to build a new university building in nearby (predominantly Protestant)Colerainerather than developing the Ulster UniversityMagee Campus. Another major government decision affecting the city was the decision to create the new town ofCraigavonoutside Belfast, which again was detrimental to the development of the city. Even in October 2005, there was perceived bias against the comparatively impoverished North West of the province, with a major civil service job contract going to Belfast.Mark Durkan, theSocial Democratic and Labour Party(SDLP) leader and Member of Parliament (MP) for Foyle was quoted in theBelfast Telegraphas saying:

template.arg: The fact is there has been consistent under-investment in the North West and a reluctance on the part of the Civil Service to see or support anything west of the Bann, except when it comes to rate increases, then they treat us equally.

article.paragraph: In July 2005, the Irish Minister for Finance,Brian Cowen, called for a joint task force to drive economic growth in the cross border region. This would have implications for Counties Londonderry, Tyrone, and Donegal across the border.
article.heading: Shopping
article.paragraph: File:Austins 2007 SMC.jpgthumbuprightAustins of DerryAustinsdepartment storeThe city is the north west's foremost shopping district, housing two large shopping centres along with numerous shop packed streets serving much of the greater county, as well asCounty TyroneTyroneandCounty DonegalDonegal. While retail developments inLetterkennyhave lessened cross-border traffic from north County Donegal,Citation neededNovember 2009the weakness of thepound sterlingover the course of 2009 made border towns such as Derry attractive to shoppers from south of the border.cite newshttp://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/poundrsquos-record-low-to-bring-a-swarm-of-euro-shoppers-14105210.htmlPound's record low to bring a swarm of euro shoppers12 December 2008Belfast Telegraph9 November 2009cite newshttp://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/business-news/northern-irelandrsquos-border-retailers-gear-up-for-a-euro-boost-this-christmas-14547191.htmlNorthern Ireland's border retailers gear up for a euro boost this Christmas2 November 2009Belfast Telegraph9 November 2009

The city centre has two main shopping centres; theFoyleside Shopping Centrewhich has 45 stores and 1430 parking spaces, and theRichmond Centre (Derry)Richmond Centre, which has 39 retail units. The Quayside Shopping Centre also serves the city-side and there is also Lisnagelvin Shopping Centre in the Waterside. These centres, as well as local-run businesses, feature numerous national and international stores. A recent addition was theCrescent Link Retail Parklocated in the Waterside with many international chain stores, including Homebase, Currys & PC World (stores combined), Carpet Right, Maplin, Argos Extra, Toys R Us, Halfords, DW Sports (formerly JJB Sports), Pets at Home, Next Home, Starbucks, McDonalds, Tesco Express and M&S Simply Food. In the short space of time that this site has been operational, it has quickly grown to become the second largest retail park in Northern Ireland (second only to Sprucefield in Lisburn).cite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/business/Crescent-Link-Retail-Park-bought.3462253.jpCrescent Link Retail Park bought for £92 m9 November 2007Derry Journal Online15 June 2008Plans have also been approved for Derry's first Asda store, which will be located at the retail park sharing a unit with Homebase.cite newshttp://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/news/derrys-first-asda-store-to-create-350-jobs-29007917.htmlDerry's first Asda store to create 350 jobs22 December 2012Belfast Telegraph31 December 2013Sainsbury's also applied for planning permission for a store at Crescent Link, but Environment MinisterAlex Attwoodturned it down.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-foyle-west-20812156Attwood gives ASDA green light for new Londonderry store21 December 2012BBC News31 December 2013

The city is also home to the world's oldest independent department store;Austins of DerryAustins. Established in 1830, Austins predatesJennersofEdinburghby 5 years,Harrodsof London by 15 years andMacy'sof New York by 25 years.cite webhttp://www.austinsstore.com/Pages/about_us/austins_in_briefAustins in BriefAustinsstore.com20 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20090817121617/http://www.austinsstore.com:80/Pages/about_us/austins_in_brief17 August 2009The store's five-storyEdwardianbuilding is located within the walled city in the area known as The Diamond.
article.heading: Landmarks
article.paragraph: File:St Eugene's Cathedral, August 2009.JPGrightthumbSt Eugene's CathedralFile:Bishop Street Courthouse, Derry - Londonderry - geograph.org.uk - 174216.jpgrightthumbBishop Street CourthouseFile:Long Tower Church, August 2009.JPGrightthumbLong Tower ChurchDerry is renowned for its architecture. This can be primarily ascribed to the formal planning of the historic walled city of Derry at the core of the modern city. This is centred on the Diamond with a collection of lateGeorgian architectureGeorgian,Victorian architectureVictorianandEdwardian architectureEdwardianbuildings maintaining the gridlines of the main thoroughfares (Shipquay Street, Ferryquay Street, Butcher Street and Bishop Street) to the City Gates.St Columb's Cathedraldoes not follow the grid pattern reinforcing its civic status. ThisChurch of IrelandCathedral was the first post-English ReformationReformationCathedral built for anAnglicanchurch. The construction of theRoman CatholicSt Eugene's Cathedralin the Bogside in the 19th-century was another major architectural addition to the city. The more recent infill buildings within the walls are of varying quality and in many cases these were low quality hurriedly constructed replacements for 1970s bomb damaged buildings.citation neededOctober 2012The Townscape Heritage Initiative has funded restoration works to key listed buildings and other older structures.

In the three centuries since their construction, the city walls have been adapted to meet the needs of a changing city. The best example of this adaptation is the insertion of three additional gates – Castle Gate, New Gate and Magazine Gate – into the walls in the course of the 19th century. Today, the fortifications form a continuous promenade around the city centre, complete with cannon, avenues of mature trees and views across Derry. Historic buildings within the city walls include St Augustine's Church, which sits on the city walls close to the site of the original monastic settlement; the copper-domed Austin's department store, which claims to the oldest such store in the world; and the imposing Greek Revival Courthouse on Bishop Street. The red-brick late-VictorianGuildhall, DerryGuildhall, also crowned by a copper dome, stands just beyond Shipquay Gate and close to the river front.

There are many museums and sites of interest in and around the city, including the Foyle Valley Railway Centre, theAmelia EarhartCentre And Wildlife Sanctuary, theApprentice Boys of DerryApprentice BoysMemorial Hall,Ballyoan Cemetery, The Bogside, numerousMurals#Northern Ireland muralsmuralsby theBogside Artists, Derry Craft Village,Free Derry Corner, O'Doherty Tower (now home to part of the Tower Museum), the Guildhall, the Harbour Museum, the Museum of Free Derry, Chapter House Museum, the Workhouse Museum, theNerve Centre, St. Columb's Park and Leisure Centre,St Eugene's Cathedral,Creggan Country Park,The Millennium Forumand theFoyle BridgeFoyleandCraigavon BridgeCraigavonbridges.

The city has seen a large boost to its economy in the form of tourism over the last few years.citation neededOctober 2012Cheap flights offered by budget airlines have enticed many people to visit the city. Tourism mainly focuses around the pubs, mainly those of Waterloo Street.citation neededOctober 2012Other attractions include museums, a vibrant shopping centre and trips to theGiant's Causeway, which is approximatelyconvert50mikmaway, though poorly connected by public transport.Lonely Planetcalled Londonderry the fourth best city in the world to see in 2013.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-foyle-west-20039650Londonderry 'world's fourth best city to visit' in 2013BBC News23 October 201228 October 2012

Future projects include the Walled City Signature Project, which intends to ensure that the city's walls become a world class tourist experience.cite webhttp://www.nitb.com/article.aspx?ArticleIDWalled City of Derry – Signature Projecthttps://web.archive.org/web/20080202030606/http://www.nitb.com/article.aspx?ArticleID2 February 2008The Industry Website of the Northern Ireland Tourist Board. Retrieved 10 September 2006.The Ilex Urban Regeneration Company is charged with delivering several landmark redevelopments. It has taken control of two former British Army barracks in the centre of the city. The Ebrington site is nearing completion and is linked to the city centre by the new Peace Bridge.
article.heading: Transport
article.paragraph: File:Foyle bridge, railside.jpgthumbrightTheFoyle Bridgeshowing Derry to Belfast rail linkThe transport network is built out of a complex array of old and modern roads and railways throughout the city and county. The city's road network also makes use of two bridges to cross theRiver Foyle, theCraigavon Bridgeand theFoyle Bridge, the longest bridge in Ireland. Derry also serves as a major transport hub for travel throughout nearbyCounty Donegal.

In spite of it being the second city of Northern Ireland (and it being the second-largest city in all ofUlster), road and rail links to other cities are below par for its standing. Many business leaders claim that government investment in the city and infrastructure has been badly lacking. The rail link to Belfast has been downgraded over the years so that presently it is not a viable alternative to the roads for industry to rely on. article.heading: Railway history
article.paragraph: File:Map Rail Ireland Viceregal Commission 1906.jpgthumbIreland's railway network in 1906Throughout the first half of the 20th century the city was served by four different railways that between them linked the city with much of the province of Ulster, plus a harbour railway network that linked the other four lines. There was also a tramway on the City side of the Foyle.
article.heading: 19th and 20th century growth
article.paragraph: Derry's first railway was theIrish gauge(RailGauge5ft3in)Londonderry and Enniskillen Railway(L&ER). Construction began in 1845 from a temporary station atLondonderry Cow Market railway stationCow Marketon the City side of the Foyle, reachedStrabanein 1847cite bookHajduckiS. Maxwell1974A Railway Atlas of IrelandNewton Abbott[[David & Charles]]0-7153-5167-2map 3and was extended fromLondonderry Cow Market railway stationCow Marketto its permanent terminus at Foyle Road in 1850.Hajducki,op. cit., inset to map 2The L&ER reachedOmaghin 1852 andEnniskillenin 1854,and was absorbed into theGreat Northern Railway (Ireland)in 1883.cite bookPattersonEdward M1962The County Donegal Railways[[David & Charles]]Dawlish10–11

TheLondonderry and Coleraine Railway(L&CR), also Irish gauge, reached the city in 1852 and opened its terminus at Waterside.TheBelfast and Northern Counties Railwayleased the line from 1861 and took it over in 1871.

TheLondonderry and Lough Swilly Railwayopened between Farland Point onLough Swillyand a temporary terminus at Pennyburn in 1863.In 1866 it extended from Pennyburn to its permanent terminus at Graving Dock.The L&LSR was Irish gauge until 1885, when it was converted toRailGauge3ftnarrow gaugefor through running with the Letterkenny Railway.

TheLondonderry PortLondonderry Port and Harbour Commissioners(LPHC) linked Graving Dock and Foyle Road stations with a railway through Middle Quay in 1867, and linked this line with Waterside station by a railway over the new Carlisle Bridge in 1868.The bridge was replaced in 1933 with the double-deckCraigavon Bridge, with the LPHC railway on its lower deck.

In 1900 theRailGauge3ftgaugeCounty Donegal Railways Joint CommitteeDonegal Railwayextended from Strabane to Derry, establishingLondonderry Victoria Road railway stationa terminus at Victoria Road. This was next to Carlisle Bridge and had a junction with the LPHC railway.The LPHC line was altered todual gaugewhich allowedRailGauge3ftgauge traffic between the Donegal Railway and L&LSR as well as Irish gauge traffic between the GNR and B&NCR. In 1906 theNorthern Counties Committee(NCC, successor to the B&NCR) and the GNR jointly took over the Donegal Railway, making it theCounty Donegal Railways Joint Committee(CDRJC).

The United Kingdom Government subsidised both the L&LSR and the Donegal Railway to build long extensions into remote parts ofCounty Donegal. By 1905 these served much of the county,Hajducki,op. cit., maps 2, 3 & 6making Derry (and also Strabane) a key rail hub for the county.

TheCity of Derry Tramwayswas opened in 1897.Hajducki,op. cit., page xviiThis was astandard gauge(RailGaugesg) line served byHorsecarhorse tramsand was never electrified.The tramway had only one line, wasconvert1.5milong, and ran along the City side of the Foyle parallel to the LPHC's line on that side of the river.Hajducki,op. cit., map 3It was closed in 1919.
article.heading: 20th century decline
article.paragraph: Thepartition of Irelandin 1922 turned the boundary with County Donegal into an international frontier. This changed trade patterns to the railways' detriment and placed border posts on every line to and from Derry except the NCC route torwsColeraine.The L&LSR crossed the border between Pennyburn and Bridge End, the CDRJC crossed just beyond Strabane, and the GNR line crossed twice between Derry and Strabane.Stops for customs inspections greatly delayed trains and disrupted timekeeping.

Over the next few years customs agreements between the two states enabled GNR trains to and from Derry to pass through the Free State without inspection unless they were scheduled to serve local stations on the west bank of the Foyle, and for goods on all railways to be carried between different parts of the Free State to pass through Northern Ireland underBonded warehousecustoms bond. However, local passenger and goods traffic continued to be delayed by customs examinations.

In the 1920s and 30s and again after the Second World War the railways also faced increasing road competition. The L&LSR closed its line in 1953, followed by the CDRJC in 1954.Hajducki,op. cit., map 39TheUlster Transport Authoritytook over the NCC in 1949 and the GNR's lines in Northern Ireland in 1958. The UTA also took over the LPHC railway, which it closed in 1962.cite bookBakerMichael H.C.1972Irish Railways since 1916London[[Ian Allan Publishing|Ian Allan]]0711002827209In accordance withUlster Transport Authority#The Benson ReportThe Benson Reportsubmitted to the Northern Ireland Government in 1963, the UTA closed the former GNR line to Derry in 1965.Baker,op. cit., page 155

Since 1965 the former L&CR line has been Derry's sole railway link. As such it has carried not only passenger services between Derry and Belfast but alsoCIfreight services using Derry as arailheadfor Donegal.
article.heading: Road network
article.paragraph: The road network has historically seen under-investment and has lacked good road connections to both Belfast and Dublin for many years.citation neededOctober 2011Long overdue, the largest road investment in the north west's history is now (2010) taking place with building of the 'A2 Broadbridge Maydown to City of Derry Airport dualling' projectcite webhttp://roadimprovements.roadsni.gov.uk/index/schemes/broadbridge/a2_broadbridge_exhibition_panels_2.htmA2 BroadBridge Maydown to City of Derry Airport Dualling Exhibition Panels | Road Improvements | Road Service Northern IrelandRoadimprovements.roadsni.gov.uk26 November 200920 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20090907025629/http://roadimprovements.roadsni.gov.uk:80/index/schemes/broadbridge/a2_broadbridge_exhibition_panels_2.htm7 September 2009and announcement of the 'A6 Londonderry to Dungiven Dualling Scheme'cite webhttp://roadimprovements.roadsni.gov.uk/index/schemes/londonderry-dungiven.htmA6 Londonderry to Dungiven Dualling Scheme | Road Improvements | Road Service Northern IrelandRoadimprovements.roadsni.gov.uk20 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20100503192755/http://roadimprovements.roadsni.gov.uk:80/index/schemes/londonderry-dungiven.htm3 May 2010which will help to reduce the travel time to Belfast.cite webhttp://www.wesleyjohnston.com/roads/a6dungiventoderry.html75% of the journey upon completion will be on either High Quality Dual Carriageway or Motorway Standard Roads.www.wesleyjohnston.com/roads22 September 2006The latter project brings a dual-carriageway link between Northern Ireland's two largest cities one step closer. The project is costing 320 million and is expected to be completed in 2016.

In October 2006 theGovernment of Irelandannounced that it was to invest 1 billion in Northern Ireland;cite webhttp://www.newsletter.co.uk/3425/It39s-trickortreat-time-with-Brown.1839311.jpIt's trick-or-treat time with BrownDempsterStephen24 October 2006www.belfasttoday.netJohnston Press Digital Publishing31 October 2006and one of the planned projects will be 'The A5 Western Transport Corridor',cite webhttp://www.roadsni.gov.uk/contractadverts-details.htm?idContract Details | Roads Service Northern IrelandRoadsni.gov.uk20 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20090608190306/http://www.roadsni.gov.uk:80/contractadverts-details.htm?id8 June 2009the complete upgrade of the A5 Derry Omagh Aughnacloy ( Dublin) road, aroundconvert90kmofflong, todual carriagewaystandard.cite webhttp://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/?jpPackage would fund biggest-ever cross-border project22 March 2007www.breakingnews.ie9 June 2007

It is not yet known if these two separate projects will connect at any point, although there have been calls for some form of connection between the two routes. In June 2008Conor Murphy, Minister for Regional Development, announced that there will be a study into the feasibility of connecting the A5 and A6.Should it proceed, the scheme would most likely run from Drumahoe to south of Prehen along the south east of the City.
article.heading: Sea
article.paragraph: File:HMS Ferret surrendered Uboats.jpguprightthumbA mass of surrendered German U-boats at their mooring at LisahallyLondonderry PortatLisahallyis the United Kingdom's most westerly port and has capacity for 30,000-ton vessels. TheLondonderry PortLondonderry Port and Harbour Commissioners(LPHC) announced record turnover, record profits and record tonnage figures for the year ended March 2008. The figures are the result of a significant capital expenditure programme for the period 2000 to 2007 of about 22 million. Tonnage handled by LPHC increased almost 65% between 2000 and 2007, according to the latestwhenOctober 2011annual results.

The port gave vital Allied service in the longest running campaign of the Second World War, theBattle of the Atlantic (19391945)Battle of the Atlantic, and saw the surrender of the German U-Boat fleet at Lisahally on 8 May 1945.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2007/aug/20/secondworldwar.northernirelandRaise the U-boat: council plans to put Nazi sub in maritime museumBowcottOwen20 August 2007[[Guardian Unlimited]]19 June 2008London
article.heading: Inland waterways
article.paragraph: The tidalRiver Foyleis navigable from the coast at Derry to approximatelyconvert10mikm0inland. In 1796, theStrabane Canalwas opened, continuing the navigation a furtherconvert4mikm0southwards toStrabane. The canal was closed in 1962.
article.heading: Education
article.paragraph: File:Magee University Derry SMC 2005.jpguprightthumbMagee Collegebecame a campus ofUlster Universityin 1969Derry is home to theMagee CollegeMagee CampusofUlster University, formerly Magee College. However, Lockwood'sA History of Magee CollegeUlster University website1960s decision to locate Northern Ireland's second university in Coleraine rather than Derry helped contribute to the formation of the civil rights movement that ultimately led toThe Troubles. Derry was the town more closely associated with higher learning, with Magee College already more than a century old by that time.A history of Irish TheatreGoogle booksNorthern Ireland during the 1960swww.irelandseye.comIn the mid-1980s a half-hearted attempt was made at rectifying this mistake by forming Magee College as a campus of theUlster Universitybut this has failed to stifle calls for the establishment of an independent University in Derry that can grow to it full potential.Derry needs big idea to get over depressionIrish News website 1 February 2009waybackhttp://www.irishnews.com/appnews/540/606/2008/2/1/579104_335361441817Derryneed.html20130608072424The campus has never thrived and currently only has 3,500 students out of a totalUlster Universitystudent population of 27,000. Ironically, although Coleraine is blamed by many in the city for 'stealing the University', it has only 5,000 students, the remaining 19,000 being based in Belfast.Ulster UniversityUlster University website
TheNorth West Regional Collegeis also based in the city. In recent years it has grown to almost 30,000 students.The North West Region Profile Derry and DonegalIreland Northwest website

One of the two oldest secondary schools in Northern Ireland is located in Derry,Foyle and Londonderry College. It was founded in 1616 by the merchant taylors and remains a popular choice. Other secondary schools includeSt. Columb's College,Oakgrove Integrated College,St Cecilia's College,St Mary's College, DerrySt Mary's College,St. Joseph's Boys' School,Lisneal College,Thornhill College,Lumen Christi College (Derry, Northern Ireland)Lumen Christi Collegeand St. Brigid's College. There are also numerous primary schools.

article.paragraph: The city is home to sports clubs and teams. Both association football andGaelic footballare popular in the area.
article.heading: Association football
article.paragraph: In association football, the city's most prominent clubs includeDerry City F.C.Derry Citywho play in theLeague of Irelandnational leagueof theRepublic of Ireland;Institute F.C.Instituteof theNIFL ChampionshipandOxford United Stars F.C.Oxford United StarsandTrojans F.C.Trojans, both of theNorthern Ireland Intermediate League.In addition to these clubs, who all play in national leagues, other clubs are based in the city. The local football league governed by theIrish Football AssociationIFAis theNorth-West Junior League, which contains many clubs from the city, such as BBOB (Boys Brigade Old Boys) and Lincoln Courts. The city's other junior league is theDerry and District Leagueand teams from the city and surrounding areas participate, including Don Boscos and Creggan Swifts. TheFoyle Cupyouth soccer tournament is held annually in the city. It has attracted many notable teams in the past, includingSV Werder BremenWerder Bremen,IFK GteborgandFerencvrosi TCFerencvros.File:Psggame.JPGthumbrightDerry City F.C.Derry Citytaking onParis Saint-Germainat theBrandywell Stadiumduring the 2006UEFA Cup

article.heading: Rugby Union
article.paragraph: Rugby Unionis also quite popular in the city, with theCity of Derry Rugby Clubsituated not far from the city centre.cite webhttp://www.cityofderryrfc.com/City of Derry Rugby Club Official WebsiteCityofderryrfc.com5 June 201020 June 2010City of Derry won both the Ulster Towns Cup and the Ulster Junior Cup in 2009.Londonderry YMCA RFC is another rugby club and is based inDrumahoewhich is just outside the city.
article.heading: Basketball
article.paragraph: The city's only basketball club isNorth Star Basketball Clubwhich has teams in theBasketball Northern Irelandsenior and junior Leagues.cite webhttp://www.northstarbasketball.com/North Star Basketball Club Official WebsiteNorthstarbasketball.com20 June 2010
article.heading: Cricket
article.paragraph: Cricketis also a popular sport in the city, particularly in the Waterside. The city is home to two cricket clubs,Brigade Cricket ClubandGlendermott Cricket Club, both of whom play in theNorth West Senior League.
article.heading: Golf
article.paragraph: Golf is also a sport which is popular with many in the City. There are two golf clubs situated in the city,City of Derry Golf ClubandFoyle International Golf Centre.
article.heading: Culture
article.paragraph: File:'Hands Across the Divide' sculpture, Derry.jpgrightthumbnail''Hands Across the Divide'' sculpture, byMaurice Harron.In recent years the city and surrounding countryside have become well known for their artistic legacy, producing Nobel Prize-winning poetSeamus Heaney,cite webhttp://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1995/heaney-bio.htmlSeamus Heaney – BiographyNobelprize.org20 June 2010poetSeamus Deane, playwrightBrian Friel,cite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/journal/Milestone-birthday-for-playwright-Brian.4859003.jpMilestone birthday for playwright Brian Friel – Derry TodayDerryjournal.com20 June 2010writer and music criticNik Cohn, artistWillie Doherty, socio-political commentator and activistEamonn McCanncite webhttp://www.derryjournal.com/17469/Meet-the-Candidates--Eamonn.6216366.jpMeet the Candidates – Eamonn McCann People Before Profit Alliance – Derry TodayDerryjournal.com20 June 2010Dead linkJanuary 2014and bands such asThe Undertones. The large political gable-wall murals of Bogside Artists, Free Derry Corner, the Foyle Film Festival, the Derry Walls, St Eugene's and St Columb's Cathedrals and the annual Halloween street carnivalcite webhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/halloween/Halloween 2009Derrycity.gov.uk2 November 200920 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20100523075400/http://www.derrycity.gov.uk:80/halloween/23 May 2010are popular tourist attractions. David Latimer. article.heading: Media
article.paragraph: The local papers theDerry Journal(known as theLondonderry Journaluntil 1880) and theLondonderry Sentinelreflect the divided history of the city: theJournalwas founded in 1772 and is Ireland's second oldest newspaper;theSentinelnewspaper was formed in 1829 when new owners of theJournalembracedCatholic Emancipation, and the editor left the paper to set up theSentinel. There are numerous radio stations receivable: the largest stations based in the city areBBC Radio Foylecite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/radiofoyle/Northern Ireland – Radio FoyleBBC20 June 2010and the commercial stationQ102.9.cite webhttp://www.q102.fm/portal/Q102.9 FMQ102.fm20 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20100330122925/http://www.q102.fm:80/portal/30 March 2010There was a locally based television station,C9TV, one of only two local or 'restricted' television services in Northern Ireland, which ceased broadcasts in 2007.
article.heading: Night-life
article.paragraph: The city's night-life is mainly focused on the weekends, with several bars and clubs providing "student nights" during the weekdays. Waterloo Street and Strand Road provide the main venues. Waterloo Street, a steep street lined with both Irish traditional and modern pubs, frequently has live rock and traditional music at night. The city is renowned for producing talented musicians and many bands perform in venues around the city, for example theSmalltown Americaduo,Fighting with WireandJetplane Landing. Numerous other young local and indeed international bands perform at theNerve Centre.
article.heading: Events

list.listitem: In 2013, Derry became the first city to be designatedUK City of Culture, having been awarded the title in July 2010.
Also in 2013 the city hostedRadio 1's Big Weekend.

The "Banks of the Foyle Hallowe'en Carnival" (known in Irish as File na Samhna) in Derry are a huge tourism boost for the city. The carnival is promoted as being the first and longest running Halloween carnival in the whole of Ireland,cite webhttp://www.derrycity.gov.uk/halloween/Banks of the Foyle Hallowe'en CarnivalDerry City Council5 September 2006yeshttps://web.archive.org/20060721232747/http://www.derrycity.gov.uk:80/halloween/21 July 2006cite webhttp://aspen.conncoll.edu/politicsandculture/page.cfm?keyMasquerading as Subversion?PelanRebeccaPolitics and Culture5 September 2006yeshttps://web.archive.org/20060309012934/http://aspen.conncoll.edu:80/politicsandculture/page.cfm?key9 March 2006It is called the largest street party in Ireland by the Derry Visitor and Convention Bureau with more than 30,000 ghoulish revellers taking to the streets annually.cite webhttp://www.irishabroad.com/news/irishpost/Travel/ireland-home-halloween-051012.aspIreland, home of HalloweenRogersMalcolmThe Irish Post5 September 2006

In March, the city hosts the Big Tickle Comedy Festival, which in 2006 featuredDara BriainandColin Murphy (comedian)Colin Murphy. In April the city plays host to theCity of Derry Jazz and Big Band Festivaland in November the Foyle Film Festival, the biggest film festival in Northern Ireland.

Every summer the city hostsTomo-Dachi, Ireland's largestAnime convention, which in July 2006 was held atMagee College,Ulster University.cite newshttp://news.ulster.ac.uk/releases/2005/1976.htmlMagee To Host Japanese Animation Convention7 December 2005news.ulster.ac.uk5 September 2006

Celtronic is a major annual electronic dance festival held at venues all around the city. The 2007 Festival featured the DJ,Erol Alkan.
TheMillennium Forumis the main theatre in the city, it holds numerous shows weekly.

On 9 December 2007 Derry entered the Guinness Book of Records when 13,000 Santas gathered to break the world record beating previous records held by Liverpool and Las Vegas.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7135400.stmSanta record bid attracts 13,000BBC28 August 20089 December 2007
